textMap.PRIMARY: 3. Joe arrives at the Smith home for VA Day
4. Juliana and Frank begin their day
5. Thomas shows Joe around his father's study
6. Juliana arrives at the Japanese Authority Building
8. Juliana arrives to her first day at work
9. Kido looks for the gun used at the Crown Prince shooting
11. Smith runs into an old friend at the airport
12. Juliana listens in on a meeting
14. Kido and Yoshida attempt to locate the gun used in the Prince shooting
15. The Smiths have a meal with Joe and Wegener

18. Juliana and Joe snoop around for answers
20. Smith and Wegener argue over the war
22. Childan asks Frank about the bullets he purchased
23. Tagomi thanks Juliana for her work
27. Juliana asks Christine for a favor

accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Joe Blake. acted by Luke Kleintank
John Smith. acted by Rufus Sewell
Helen Smith. acted by Chelah Horsdal
Juliana Crain. acted by Alexa Davalos
Frank Frink. acted by Rupert Evans
Nobusuke Tagomi. acted by Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa
Sergeant Yoshida. acted by Lee Shorten
Inspector Kido. acted by Joel de la Fuente
Arnold Walker. acted by Daniel Roebuck
Rudolph Wegener. acted by Carsten Norgaard
Oberfeuhrer Oliver Diels. acted by Alex Zahara
Ambassador Hugo Reiss. acted by Bernhard Forcher
Ed McCarthy. acted by DJ Qualls
Harlan Wyndam-Matson. acted by Jack Kehler

textMap.PRIMARY: In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," VA day is celebrated on September 18th, and takes the place of our Memorial Day or VE/VJ Day. The production team wanted to portray one of the underlying themes of the show: Violence on the American Dream. Classic bunting with a Nazi twist. All of this is meant to pacify the public into thinking things haven't changed that much. The 4th of July is no longer celebrated in this world.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Greater Nazi Reich is a prosperous and technologically advanced state. Helen is the pinnacle of Nazi traditionalism and sophistication. Her wardrobe reflects her place in society as the wife of a high ranking Nazi officer.

The addition of aprons to the Smith women's wardrobe is a design choice by "The Man in the High Castle" costume department to combine traditional and wholesome American trends in the context of this Nazi nuclear family.

Expulsion from the Hitler Youth was a very serious matter. It meant that you could never join the party, join the military, or have a career as an academic. It also meant that the parents of the expelled youth would receive no government child support and/or be fined for their child's behavior. Between 1933 and 1944, over 2700 youths were expelled.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," baseball is frowned upon as a uniquely American sport. Hitler had a great respect for athletics and believed that the superior Aryan race should dominate in this field.
The design of the Greater Nazi Reich airport aspires to the concrete mid-century modernism of the existing NYC airports & Brazil's capital.

Prior to WW2, Japan celebrated the Army and the Navy on two separate days. However, having lost the war and losing most of their military, any commemoration days ceased. The "Japanese Self-Defense Forces" was established in 1954, with its commemoration day celebrated on November 1st. However, in the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Japanese would have continued to celebrate the Army and Navy, due to their success in the war - yet would have chosen one day to celebrate the combined military forces.

The Night of the Long Knives (1934), during which Hitler eliminated the SA's leadership, made it clear to all of Germany what would happen should anyone rebel against the regime. Despite this, students still set up protest movements against Hitler.

Riesling is the most celebrated variety of grape in Germany. The largest vineyard growing the Riesling grape is in Germany, the production of which is relied heavily upon by the wine industry. The history of Riesling is a little mysterious, but evidence suggests that the first appearance was in a German monastery in 1435.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," Betty Kasura, being a jet setting fashionista, would have collected fashionable pieces from her far flung travels. This Moroccan tunic is a private fashion treat for this sophisticated glamour girl in her mid-century modern life.
Whenever Hitler spoke publicly there was never a shortage of Nazi iconography. Hitler was a master at utilizing visual and verbal propaganda as a tool of coercion and manipulation over his people.

Among "The Man in the High Castle" production design team and producers there was much debate about what the Smith home should look like. How would a top figure within the Reich, someone at Smith's level and stature, live? Because Smith is an idealist and believes the national socialism of the Nazi party is improving America, he would live with a sense of humility. A classic upper middle class American home reflects his belief in a more reserved, orderly society. The interior color palette of the living room is drawn from that of the Luftwaffe uniform (grey) and the dining room drawn from Hitler's camel colored jacket.

"The Man in the High Castle" costume department approached Juliana's style being both simple and practical. She is a lower class member of Japanese San Francisco society and doesn't have much money or access to new or fashionable clothing. As she begins to forge her way into the workplace she must dress in appropriate attire to fit the hierarchy that surrounds her. The goal was to show Juliana successfully figuring out how to dress for this new office job by utilizing the pieces she already owned or were handed down to her by her mother.

Legend has it that Italian monks first made pretzels in 610 AD by folding dough into the shape of crossing one's arms in prayer. These were then given to children in reward for saying their prayers. Germany became the country most associated with pretzels because children would wear necklaces in the shape of pretzels during New Year celebrations for good luck for the coming year. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Greater Nazi Reich would have adopted them as their favorite snack.

The Three Monkeys proverb originates from a carving in the Nikko Tosho-hu Shrine in Japan, believed to have been carved in the 17th Century by Hidari Jongoro. It depicts three monkeys sitting in a row, one covering its eyes, one its mouth and the other, its ears, widely translated as 'see no evil, speak no evil, hear no evil'. It is thought to incorporate ideas from the Chinese philosopher Confucius' Code of Conduct.

An "Honorary Aryan" was a term bestowed on those to certify them as part of the Aryan race, if they were not biologically so. Hitler granted the Japanese, "Honorary Aryans" and he believed that the racial superiority they believed for themselves was true. This greatly improved German-Japanese relations throughout the war.

The origins of this practice are uncertain, but when there is a death in a Jewish family, all the mirrors in the house are covered until the end of Shiva (the mourning period). Shiva is time to reflect upon the inner self of the deceased - the mirror is the opposite of that, it reflects the external qualities of ourselves.

"Kaddish," the mourner's prayer, is said in honor of the deceased, and has been recited for over 2000 years. Normally there would be ten people present to recite the Kaddish. Reciting the Kaddish is one of Judaism's Mitzvahs - a true act of kindness. For a deceased parent, the Kaddish is recited daily for 11 months. For a spouse, child or sibling it is recited for 30 days.
